admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Performance Audit Report
            (PPAR) represents a performance audit of two Philippines
            projects: the Manila Urban Development Project; and the
            Second Urban Development Project. For the, first project,
            loans 1282-PH and 1272-PH for $32.0 million equivalent were
            approved on May 27, 1976, including a $10.0 million Third
            Window Intermediate Term Loan (No. 1272-0-PH). A
            supplementary loan (1282-1-PH) for $10.5 million equivalent
            was approved in February 1984 under the Bank's Program
            of Special Assistance to Member Countries 1983-84. Bank
            Group financing for the second project was provided through
            Loan 1647-PH for $26.7 million equivalent, approved on
            December 21, 1978. The final loan disbursement on the first
            project was made in July 1986 and the undisbursed balance of
            $3.2 million equivalent was cancelled. For the second
            project, the final disbursement was made July 24, 1985 and
            the undisbursed balance of $1.4 million equivalent was
            cancelled. The PPAR consists of the following: (a) a Project
            Completion Report (PCR) on the first project, dated April
            1986, prepared by the East Asia and Pacific Regional Office;
            (b) a PCR on the second project, dated December 1986,
            prepared by the Borrower and supplemented by the East Asia
            and Pacific Region memorandum of December 31, 1986; and (c)
            a Project Performance Audit Memorandum (PPAM) prepared by
            the Operations Evaluation Department (OED). At the sector
            level, the Audit attributes the modest policy gains achieved
            by the projects largely to the lack of an effective dialogue
            between the Borrower and the Bank on several important
            sector issues such as housing finance and relocation of
            squatter settlements. It is conceivable that by slowing down
            the pace of sector lending the Bank might have better
            assisted the Borrower in Instituting needed sector policy
            reforms. Fortunately, however, both the Region and the
            Borrower report the lessons learned from the experience of
            these first two projects are presently being applied to the
            restructuring of on-going operations and are likely to
            improve future project performance.
